captions.text: Da, Da, Da, Da.. Duh Duh Dum!
Ba da da da  da dum!!!
But you must not pass the great seal, that is the boundary.
What will happen if we cross the seal?
Oh, you will be mortal again.

But if you remove the grail, this whole
place will collapse and everyone will die.
So what's the point then in having you stand guard here for over 700 years??
I mean, it seems like you could have just carved everything you just told me on the wall or something

and then you wouldn't have to sit here
alone the whole time.
Tip toe, tip toe, don't step on the wrong one ...
Oh, I hope my girlfriend is still alive!
Ok dad, we're out of here.
Hahahaha! We got the grail, we got the grail!
We got the grail!! We got the grail!! we got the grail!!
But she is one of them!
Wh- eh? How do you know that?
Dad, how do you know that?
She and I... well.... you know.
What kind of person does that?!?
I don't know what he's talking about!
You knew I was his son, Elsa.
Uhh, I think I'm gonna throw up.
Well it isn't that disgusting is it?
Ya, that is pretty messed up
But she's one of them! But she's one of them.
But she's... kind of sounds like I'm saying "butt cheese"

comments.author: Luke Nance

comments.text:
+Luke Nance I have a theory that explains a little more about why they 
needed a guard at all (after all, no one can abuse the power of the Grail 
so why need someone to protect it?). I think that they had someone 
protecting it not so much as to prevent abuse, but for the fact that they 
are protecting a religious artifact that they don't want the Saracens to 
get (or something like that). So they needed someone to guard it, and once 
Indy passed the test he tried to give the Protector role to Indy (as he had 
just shown that he was too old to really protect the Grail) fully believing 
that the Crusades were still going on (especially since his brothers didn't 
come to tell him otherwise, probably died before the Crusades ended).

comments.text:
+ThePCguy17 When the Knight left, he was hundreds of years old, so his true 
age was reflected after he left the chamber (he shriveled up and died). 
 Henry and Jr. were still the same age when they left, so the loss of the 
grail's powers had no effect on them. As for how Jones Sr. left without a

comments.author: Gloria Achilli

comments.text: If magic has no rules or consistency, then it's wish granting, not magic.
comments.author: ThePCguy17

comments.text: It's magic!
comments.author: Taylor Avalos

comments.text:
+Lord Andrak

My guess is that it does have healing powers, but cannot maintain youth 
after crossing the seal.
comments.author: GojyotheFeared

comments.text:
+ThePCguy17 Well as has been pointed out the grail heals Henry Sr. and thus 
the wound no longer exists, However we are unsure as to the level of 
healing the grail does, By the fact that the knights have aged to an old 
knight and not kept his youth that I assume he first arrived with, then it 
does not prevent the aging process, so the grail appears to help speed up 
and provide the energy required for normal body processes such as healing 
and though this might slow down aging to a degree it would not prevent it.
  
The first main theory I have for the 700 year old knight that has appeared 
to age is if the temple/grail is keeping his body in a form of 
magical/divine stasis which could then explain why the body would 
disintegrate rapidly once the magic is removed a.k.a. crossing the seal.
The second theory is if this is not the case and the knight has been kept 
alive by constant healing which "some how" prevents the body from switching 
off various processes then the knight would be capable of crossing the seal 
and age as though he was the approximate the age as to which his body has 
been retained (which appeared about 70+).
The first theory is just saying, its divine magic the knight cannot die and 
his body processes will not switch off.
The second theory is constant regeneration of the cells, to their original 
state, not replace mind you just fixing the cells.

tldr;

Returning to Henry Sr and why he does not die once crossing the seal, his 
healing process is much simpler and no longer requires any additional magic 
to maintain as it was a once off heal, the wound would have no reason to 
reopen once the magic was removed.
comments.author: Lord Andrak

comments.text: +GojyotheFeared No. They nitpick things, I nitpick them. I feel justified.
comments.author: ThePCguy17

comments.text:
+ThePCguy17

And besides. It's not actually what happens in the show.

It's just something to laugh at as in, "wouldn't be hilarious if it 
happened this way?" thing.

Just enjoy and stop nit picking.
comments.author: GojyotheFeared

comments.text:
+ThePCguy17

Because without immortality, your body begins to catch up to your actual 
age.

And advanced age would be met with rapid aging followed by death for a 
centuries old being.

+Phan Lương But why is age different? Why can't the grail preserve you at a

The grail heals all wounds, permanently. When u cross the age that u should 
have died, it keeps healing you so that u will not. So when u leave the 
cave, well, the grail stops healing and u will die immediately from the new 
wounds caused by aging past the age u should have died.

can process.

That's why.

comments.author: MrCaptainRoscoe

comments.text:
I've got a rather important question about the Last Crusade, an enormous 
plot-hole that was never explained and no one ever brings up: HOW IN THE 
HELL DID KAZIM NOW THAT INDIANA'S DAD WAS BEING KEPT IN THE CASTLE 
BRUNWALD?!!! Think about it: Kazim tries to stop the Nazis from getting the 
Grail, so it's obvious that he wasn't allied with them, and that and the 
fact that it is one of the most crucial plot points in the whole movie. If 
Kazim hadn't told Indy where his dad was, than he never would have found 
his dad and they wouldn't have gone after the grail, and there would be no 
movie. So Kazim desperately doesn't want the Nazis to find the Grail, yet 
he's supposed to somehow know where Indy's dad was? It's one of the biggest 
unexplained plot holes in the entire franchise,and yet I have literally 
never heard anyone bring it up. In the first draft of the Last Crusade, 
Kazim (named Kemal in this draft of the story) was the main villain. He is 
a Hatayn secret agent who allies with the Nazis because he wants to Grail 
for the Glory of his people. He and Colonel Vogel try to kill Indy and Elsa 
in the Venice scene. Walter Donovan (Walter Chandler in this draft) falls 
to his death with the tank, and Kemal shoots Indy's dad in the temple, and 
then dies from drinking the wrong chalice. Later, Colonel Vogel crushed is 
crushed by a boulder while stealing the grail, and Elsa falls into 
everlasting darkness. In this draft, it would have made so much more sense 
how Kazim (or Kemal) knew where Indy's dad was because he was originally 
allied with the Nazis, but screenwriter Jeffrey Boam, in the final draft of 
the film, changed Kemal to Kazim and Chanlder to Donovan, and made Donovan 
the main villain. So it was never explained how someone who had NO ties to 
Germany knew where Indy's father was. Also, no one has EVER brought this 
obvious plot-hole up. As a side note, I kinda wish Kazim was the main bad 
guy, as Kevork Malikyan would have made a pretty badass villain, but I'm 
getting of topic. So how did Kazim know where Indy's dad was? Any Ideas?   ﻿
comments.author: Ken Kerrison

comments.text:
I put it up to espionage. It was shown that that was one of their 
functions in the third act of the film one the antagonists stop for gear 
and vehicles.

Their duty is to protect the Grail. The man most likely to find it would be 
of interest but what happened to this man? He was taken captive. Hell, I 
bet they just asked where.

Is it far fetched to think information in entirely unattainable in an age 
where spies were almost everywhere? It is stuff done in the shadows, 
off-screen. This gets our imagination going. I accept their capabilities 
based on the evidence shown in the film.

comments.author: ReaLife HD

comments.text:
+How It Should Have Ended   I normally agree with your endings, but maybe 
using the grail to setup a hospital would have been better?  I mean, just 
have a fountain with running water from the cup and anyone who touches the 
water is instantly healed.  Wouldn't that have been a better ending? 
 Instant cure to any/all disease/virus...?  No?  And even if it fell deep 
into the earth we're talking about INSTANT HEALING FOR ALL DISEASE?  No 
reason to excavate?  No more HIV/Cancer/ect.  And they never went back for 
it? Ever???  NO ONE went back for it?﻿

comments.text:

stopping you from aging at all just making you very very old after several 
hundred years.

Not to mention a security system that's pretty much almost grantee nobody 
is going to escape with a now useless grail if ever leave the seal so its 
kinda pointless to stay in there. only thing that grail is used for is 
bargain rights that you got a cup that Jesus drank from nothing more
